question: Question_03
statement:
Find all three-digit combinations that can occur as the last three
digits of $\displaystyle a^{100}$ where \emph{a} ranges over the
integers. Give a simple criterion for predicting which of these
possibilities occurs for a given \emph{a} without computing
$\displaystyle a^{100}$. Prove that your criterion is correct.

Hint: Investigate $\displaystyle a^{100}$ modulo 8 and modulo 125
separately, then use the Chinese Remainder Theorem.
sols:
We proceed as in the hints. Modulo 8, we have that if \emph{a} is even,
then the residue of this number is 0 modulo 8. If it is odd, then
Euler's Theorem tells us that since
$\displaystyle \phi(8) = 8(1-1/2) = 4$, we have

$a^{100} = (a^{4})^{25} = (a^{\phi(8)})^{25} \equiv 1^{25} \equiv 1 \mod{8}$

Similarly, modulo 125 we have that if 5 divides \emph{a}, then the
residue is 0 and otherwise, Euler's Theorem tells us that since
$\displaystyle \phi(125) = 5^{3}(1-1/5) = 100$, we have

$a^{100} = a^{\phi(125)}  \equiv 1 \mod{125}$

This gives us four possible systems. Either

\begin{align*}
a^{100} \equiv 0 \mod{8} \quad &\text{and} \quad a^{100} \equiv 0 \mod{125}\\
a^{100} \equiv 1 \mod{8} \quad &\text{and} \quad a^{100} \equiv 0 \mod{125}\\
a^{100} \equiv 0 \mod{8} \quad &\text{and} \quad a^{100} \equiv 1 \mod{125}\\
a^{100} \equiv 1 \mod{8} \quad &\text{and} \quad a^{100} \equiv 1 \mod{125}\end{align*}

As 8 and 125 are coprime, we have via the Chinese Remainder Theorem that
there exists a unique solution to each of these system of equations
modulo 1000 (the product of 8 and 125). We break this down into cases.

\textbf{Case 1:}
$\displaystyle a^{100} \equiv 0 \mod{8} \quad \text{and} \quad a^{100} \equiv 0 \mod{125}$.
This case occurs when 10 divides \emph{a}. In this case, by inspection,
we can see that the last three digits here are given by 000 since 0 is
the unique solution to this system.

\textbf{Case 2:}
$\displaystyle a^{100} \equiv 1 \mod{8} \quad \text{and} \quad a^{100} \equiv 0 \mod{125}$.
This occurs when \emph{a} is odd and divisible by 5. In this case, we
have that $\displaystyle a^{100} = 1 + 8s$ and so
$\displaystyle 1 + 8s \equiv 0 \mod{125}$. The inverse of 8 modulo 125
is given by the Euclidean algorithm:

\begin{align*}
125 &= 8(15) + 5\\
8 &= 5(1) + 3\\
5 &= 3(1) +2\\
3 &= 2(1) + 1\end{align*}

and back substituting gives

\begin{align*}
1 &= 3 - 2(1)\\
1 &= 3 - (5-3(1))(1)\\
1 &= 3(2) - 5(1)\\
1 &= (8-5(1))(2) - 5(1)\\
1 &= 8(2)-5(3)\\
1 &= 8(2)-(125-8(15))(3)\\
1 &= 8(47)-125(3)\end{align*}

so the inverse is 47. Thus

\begin{align*}
8s &\equiv -1 \mod{125}\\
8(47)s &\equiv -47 \mod{125}\\
s &\equiv 125-47 \mod{125}\\
s &\equiv 78 \mod{125}\end{align*}

so $\displaystyle s = 78 + 125t$. Thus recalling that
$\displaystyle a^{100} = 1 + 8s$ we have that

$\displaystyle a^{100} = 1 + 8(78 + 125t) = 1 + 624 + 1000t = 625 + 1000t$

and so the last 3 digits are 625 in this case.

\textbf{Case 3:}
$\displaystyle a^{100} \equiv 0 \mod{8} \quad \text{and} \quad a^{100} \equiv 1 \mod{125}$.
This occurs when \emph{a} is even and not divisible by 5. In this case,
we have that $\displaystyle a^{100} = 8s$ and so
$\displaystyle 8s \equiv 1 \mod{125}$. The inverse of 8 modulo 125 as
computed above is 47. Thus $\displaystyle s \equiv 47 \mod{125}$ and
hence $\displaystyle s = 47 + 125t$. Thus recalling that
$\displaystyle a^{100} = 8s$ we have that

$\displaystyle a^{100} = 8s = 8(47 + 125t) = 376 + 1000t$

and so the last 3 digits are 376 in this case.

\textbf{Case 4:}
$\displaystyle a^{100} \equiv 1 \mod{8} \quad \text{and} \quad a^{100} \equiv 1 \mod{125}$.
This occurs when \emph{a} is odd and not divisible by 5. In this case,
we have that $\displaystyle a^{100} = 1 + 8s$ and so
$\displaystyle 1 + 8s \equiv 1 \mod{125}$. The inverse of 8 modulo 125
as computed above is 47. Thus $\displaystyle s \equiv 0 \mod{125}$ and
hence $\displaystyle s = 0 + 125t$. Thus recalling that
$\displaystyle a^{100} = 1 + 8s$ we have that

$\displaystyle a^{100} = 1 + 8s = 1 + 8(0 + 125t) = 1 + 1000t$

and so the last 3 digits are 001 in this case. This completes all cases.
hints:
The hint in the problem statement does give you a good starting point.
Use Euler's Theorem to help with the reduction computations.
